name: Payment for Successful Additional Weld Test
rule_text: Any welder who is required to do additional testing by the Employer, shall be paid for weld time of four (4) hours per successful test
summary: Welders who successfully complete an additional weld test required by the employer will be paid for four hours of weld time for that test.
reasoning: This rule specifies a flat-rate payment for time spent on a work-related task (weld testing), which is a form of compensation for labor time.

name: Payment for Successful Single Plate Weld Test
rule_text: (excluding the boiler ¼ Down Hand Plate or other single ¼ plate test, will be paid two (2) hours).
summary: For specific single plate weld tests, such as the boiler ¼ Down Hand Plate test, a successful welder will be paid for two hours instead of the standard four hours for other additional tests.
logical_representation: IF test_type (llm) IN ['BOILER_1/4_DOWN_HAND_PLATE', 'SINGLE_1/4_PLATE_TEST'] AND test_result (Unsupported) == 'SUCCESS' -> PAY(2_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule defines an exception to the general test payment, specifying a different flat-rate payment for specific types of tests, which is compensation for labor time.

name: Maximum Payment for Three-Plate Additional Test
rule_text: Additional test consists of three plates welded in the vertical, horizontal and overhead positions and will be paid a maximum of four (4) hours total, upon successful completion.
summary: An 'additional test' involving three plates (vertical, horizontal, overhead) has a maximum total payment of four hours upon successful completion.
reasoning: This rule sets a cap on the payment for a specific work-related task, directly governing how labor time is compensated.

name: Payment for Abbreviated Plate Test
rule_text: Those requested to take an abbreviated version of the plate test will be compensated at one and a half (1.5) hours for each successful plate test.
summary: Welders who successfully complete an abbreviated plate test will be paid one and a half hours for each successful plate.
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific flat-rate payment for a type of weld test, which is compensation for labor time.

name: No Payment for Failed Weld Tests
rule_text: In any event a welder will not be paid for a failed test.
summary: Welders are not entitled to any payment for a welding test that they fail.
reasoning: This rule sets a condition for payment related to a work activity, defining when compensation for labor time is withheld.

name: Option for Second Weld Test
rule_text: At the sole discretion of the Weld Test Examiner, the welder may be granted the opportunity to take a second test.
summary: If a welder fails a test, the Weld Test Examiner has the discretion to allow the welder to take the test a second time.
logical_representation: IF test_result (Unsupported) == 'FAIL' AND weld_test_examiner_discretion (llm) == true -> ALLOW(SECOND_TEST_ATTEMPT)
reasoning: This rule outlines a condition that could lead to a paid work activity (a successful second test), making it relevant to how labor time and compensation are managed.

name: Travel Allowance for Job Site Testing
rule_text: If a welder is required to test at the job site, the welder shall be paid for any applicable travel allowance, but not for the failed test.
summary: Welders required to test at a job site are eligible for applicable travel allowances, regardless of whether they pass the test. However, they will not be paid for the test time itself if they fail.
reasoning: This rule grants a specific monetary allowance for travel, which falls under the category of subsistence and travel-related entitlements.

name: Payment for Partial Success in Multiple Tests
rule_text: If an Employer is requesting more than three (3) tests per welder and a welder has successfully completed three (3) of four (4) tests, the Employer may retain the welder and pay for the three (3) successful weld test. If the Employer decides not to retain the welder, he or she will be paid for the three (3) successful weld tests.
summary: If an employer requests more than three tests and the welder passes three of them, the welder will be paid for the three successful tests, regardless of whether the employer chooses to hire them or not.
reasoning: This rule specifies payment conditions for a specific scenario of partial success in work-related testing, directly governing compensation for labor time.

name: Employer Responsibility for Testing Costs
rule_text: For every required test and any examiner permitted second test the Employer will pay the transfer fees, materials and inspector fees.
summary: The employer is responsible for paying all associated costs for required welding tests, including any permitted second attempts. These costs include transfer fees, materials, and inspector fees.
logical_representation: IF test_attempt (llm) IN ['INITIAL', 'EXAMINER_PERMITTED_SECOND_TEST'] -> EMPLOYER_PAYS(transfer_fees, materials, inspector_fees)
reasoning: This rule details the financial obligations of the employer related to a work activity (testing). While not a direct payment to the employee, it is a cost of labor and fits best within the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic as it's directly tied to the performance of a work-related test.

name: Payment for Secondary Test Time
rule_text: Should a secondary test be required by the Employer, the employee shall be paid for the time required to take such a test.
summary: If an employer requires an employee to take a secondary test, the employee must be paid for the actual time spent taking that test.
reasoning: This rule dictates that time spent on a required test is compensable, directly addressing how worked time is calculated and paid.

name: Practice Material for Non-Standard Tests
rule_text: When a welder is required to perform a test of a type other than a standard Provincial test, the Employer shall, on request, make available suitable material to allow a brief period of practice prior to taking the actual test.
summary: For non-standard provincial tests, welders can request and must be provided with suitable materials for a brief practice session before the actual test.
logical_representation: IF test_type (llm) != 'STANDARD_PROVINCIAL_TEST' AND employee_request (llm) == true -> PROVIDE(PRACTICE_MATERIAL)
reasoning: This rule provides an entitlement (practice materials) directly related to the performance of a work activity (testing), and thus falls under the scope of rules governing labor and work conditions.

name: Travel Reimbursement for Out-of-Town Tests
rule_text: Any welder possessing a current Provincial Government welding certificate of qualification, who is instructed to proceed to take tests, necessitating their having to travel outside of the city limits of the city in which they reside or are employed, shall be reimbursed in an amount necessary to compensate them for travel allowance, transportation, travel expenses, subsistence allowance, if applicable.
summary: Certified welders who must travel outside their city of residence or employment for a required test will be reimbursed for travel allowance, transportation, travel expenses, and subsistence allowance if applicable.
logical_representation: IF has_provincial_welding_certificate (llm) == true AND test_location_outside_city_limits (llm) == true -> REIMBURSE(travel_allowance, transportation, travel_expenses, subsistence_allowance)
reasoning: This rule explicitly details entitlements for travel and subsistence allowances, which are the core focus of this topic.

name: Mutual Agreement on Test Costs and Location
rule_text: The Employer and the Local Lodge will communicate and mutually agree to related costs and test location(s) before proceeding with the testing.
summary: Before proceeding with out-of-town testing, the employer and the Local Lodge must communicate and mutually agree on the associated costs and the location of the test.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: Employer and union_local (Unsupported) must mutually agree on costs and location before testing proceeds.
reasoning: This rule is a procedural requirement directly linked to the provision of travel and subsistence allowances described in the same article, making it part of that topic.

name: Provision of Test Papers upon Passing
rule_text: Welders passing a test will be furnished a copy of the test papers from the Employer or party requiring the test within thirty (30) days, or upon completion of the job, whichever is sooner, provided they are available at that time; otherwise the Employer will provide a letter confirming the test and the results.
summary: Welders who pass a test must be given a copy of their test papers within 30 days or at the job's completion, whichever comes first. If papers are unavailable, a confirmation letter must be provided.
reasoning: This rule describes an entitlement that is a direct outcome of a work-related activity (testing). It's a non-monetary benefit tied to labor performance, fitting within the broader category of work rules.

name: Fair Conditions for Provincial Certification Tests
rule_text: Where a welder is to take an official Provincial test on which the issuance or re-issuance of their certificate will depend, they shall not be required to do so under conditions which would unfairly affect their ability to perform the test.
summary: Welders taking an official Provincial certification test must be provided with fair testing conditions that do not negatively impact their performance.
reasoning: This rule governs the conditions under which work (a test) is performed, which is a fundamental aspect of labor rules.

name: Test Conditions for Other Tests
rule_text: For other tests, the Employer may prescribe test conditions approximating, but not exceeding, conditions which may be encountered on the job.
summary: For tests other than official Provincial certifications, the employer can set test conditions that are similar to, but not more difficult than, actual job site conditions.
reasoning: This rule sets parameters for working conditions during a specific work activity (testing), placing it within the scope of labor time and conditions.

name: Right to Complete a Test
rule_text: Welders required to take any test shall be allowed to complete the test.
summary: Once a welder begins a required test, they must be allowed to finish it.
reasoning: This rule establishes a right for an employee during a work-related activity, directly relating to the rules governing labor performance.

name: Forfeiture of Pay for Failure to Report to Work
rule_text: Any welder who successfully completes the welding test, but fails to report for work as notified, without a bona fide reason acceptable to the Employer, will not be eligible for any payment, including testing time and other allowances, as set out in Article 7.00.
summary: A welder who passes a test but then fails to show up for work as scheduled, without an acceptable reason, will forfeit all payments and allowances related to the test.
logical_representation: IF test_result (Unsupported) == 'SUCCESS' AND employee_reports_to_work (llm) == false AND has_bona_fide_reason (llm) == false -> FORFEIT(ALL_PAYMENT_AND_ALLOWANCES)
reasoning: This rule outlines a condition that results in the forfeiture of payment for worked time and associated allowances, making it a critical rule for labor compensation.

name: Second Test Opportunity for Pre-Job Test Failure
rule_text: Any welder required to take a pre-job welding test for employment with an Employer and fails the required weld test, the welder may be granted the opportunity to take a second test.
summary: If a welder fails a required pre-employment welding test, they may be given a chance to take the test a second time.
reasoning: This rule provides a condition for a potential re-test, which is a work-related activity that could lead to compensation, therefore it relates to the administration of labor time.

name: Work Guarantee Disclaimer
rule_text: The Employer does not guarantee to provide work to any employee for regularly assigned hours or any other hours, except as provided for in Article 18.00.
summary: The employer does not guarantee a set number of work hours for any employee, except as specified elsewhere in the agreement.
reasoning: This rule establishes a fundamental condition regarding the guarantee of work hours, which is foundational to how worked time is considered. It is a constraint on work availability, thus falling under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Schedule Window Variance by Mutual Agreement
rule_text: Variances beyond one (1) hour of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. shall be agreed mutually between the Employer and the Local Lodge Business Manager/Secretary-Treasurer. The one (1) hour variance is conditional upon the Employer giving the Local Lodge and affected employees appropriate advance notice.
summary: Changes to the standard 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. work window of more than one hour require mutual agreement. Changes within one hour are permitted if the employer provides advance notice.
logical_representation: IF schedule_variance_hours (llm) > 1 -> REQUIRES(is_mutual_agreement (llm) == true) AND IF schedule_variance_hours (llm) <= 1 -> REQUIRES(is_advance_notice_given (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule governs the conditions under which the standard working hours can be changed, directly impacting how work time is scheduled and compensated. It is classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Overtime for Unilateral Schedule Change
rule_text: If the foregoing starting or quitting times are changed without mutual agreement, applicable overtime rates shall be paid for any time worked before or after the above hours as a result of the change of times.
summary: If the employer changes the start or end times of a shift without mutual agreement, any time worked outside the originally scheduled hours must be paid at overtime rates.
logical_representation: IF is_unilateral_schedule_change (llm) == true -> PAY(OT_RATE) for hours worked outside original schedule
reasoning: This rule defines a specific condition under which overtime rates are applied, which is a core component of categorizing and compensating worked hours. Therefore, it falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: CWW Makeup Day Minimum Hours
rule_text: In no case shall the time scheduled on a make-up day be less than eight (8) hours except where weather conditions dictate otherwise.
summary: A make-up day must be scheduled for at least eight hours, unless bad weather prevents it.
reasoning: This rule sets a minimum duration for a specific type of workday, which is a rule governing the scheduling and compensation of worked hours. This falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: CWW Makeup Day is Voluntary
rule_text: All time worked on a make-up day will be at the employee's choice.
summary: Working on a make-up day is optional for the employee.
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition of employment for a specific workday (make-up day), defining it as voluntary. This is a rule about the conditions of worked time, thus fitting into LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Shift Length Guarantee (Other Trades)
rule_text: Employees will not be required to work less than the regular assigned hours because of the starting or quitting time of any other trade on the job.
summary: An employee's full shift hours are guaranteed and cannot be cut short due to the work schedules of other trades on the same job site.
reasoning: This rule provides a guarantee of hours under specific circumstances, ensuring employees receive their full scheduled workday. This guarantee of worked time falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Penalty for Displaced Lunch Break
rule_text: An employee shall not be required to work during their regular lunch break except in emergency or special circumstances, in which case, they will receive a re-assigned one-half (½) hour lunch break. If this break falls outside the regular lunch break established on the job, they shall receive an additional allowance of one-half (½) hour of pay at straight time rates which shall be in addition to their regular straight time hours.
summary: If an employee works through their regular lunch break for an emergency, they get a rescheduled 30-minute break. If this rescheduled break is outside the normal lunch period, the employee receives an extra 30 minutes of pay at straight-time rates.
logical_representation: IF work_during_lunch (llm) == true AND reassigned_lunch_outside_normal_window (llm) == true -> PAY(0.5_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule provides a monetary compensation (an allowance of pay) for a disruption to the workday structure. Since it results in additional paid time, it is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Break Schedule Change Notification
rule_text: A change in the scheduling of a break will normally be communicated to the affected employees prior to the end of the work cycle before the change.
summary: If the employer changes the break schedule, they are expected to notify the affected employees before the end of the work cycle preceding the change.
reasoning: This rule outlines a procedural requirement related to the scheduling of work and breaks. It is a condition governing the administration of the workday, placing it within the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Maximum Time Between Shifts
rule_text: Second (2 nd ) and third (3 rd ) shifts shall commence not later than one (1) hour after the completion of the preceding shift, except where this is prevented by conditions or requirements beyond the control of the Employer.
summary: The afternoon and night shifts must begin within one hour of the previous shift's end, unless this is made impossible by circumstances outside the employer's control.
logical_representation: IF uncontrollable_condition (llm) == false AND (shift_number (llm) == 2 OR shift_number (llm) == 3) -> CONSTRAINT(inter_shift_break_duration (llm) <= 1)
reasoning: This rule imposes a constraint on the scheduling of work hours, specifically the transition time between shifts, which is an element of managing and defining worked time.

name: Second and Third Shift Premium
rule_text:
A shift premium shall apply on all hours worked on second (2 nd ) and third (3 rd ) shifts at the rates as set out in the Wage and Benefit Schedule.

All shift premium hours will be paid at a rate of four dollars and fifty cents ($4.50) per hour.
summary: Employees working on the second (afternoon) or third (night) shift will receive an additional $4.50 per hour as a shift premium for all hours worked on those shifts.
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific monetary premium for hours worked during certain shifts. This is a direct rule for calculating pay based on the time work is performed, which is a core component of labor worked time.

name: Insufficient Rest Period Penalty
rule_text: When an employee is required to return to work without an eight (8) hour break, all work performed shall be paid for at the applicable overtime rates, until such time as the employee receives an eight (8) hour break.
summary: If an employee is required to work without having at least an eight-hour break since their last shift, all work performed will be paid at overtime rates until they are given an eight-hour break.
reasoning: This rule defines a condition (insufficient rest) that changes the pay categorization of worked hours to overtime. Re-categorizing time buckets is a fundamental aspect of labor worked time.

name: Voluntary Unscheduled Overtime
rule_text: Any unscheduled overtime will be voluntary and worked at the employees' discretion.
summary: Employees are not required to work unscheduled overtime; it is their choice.
reasoning: This rule defines a condition related to the obligation to work overtime hours, which is a facet of labor time management.

name: Meal Break Duration
rule_text: All overtime meal breaks will be thirty (30) minutes in duration and will be paid for at straight time rates.
summary: All overtime meal breaks are 30 minutes long and are paid at the employee's straight time rate.
logical_representation: IF overtime_meal_break_provided (llm) == true -> DURATION(30_minutes) AND PAY(30_minutes_at_ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the duration and pay for a meal break, which is a direct component of a meal-related entitlement. It also touches on how time is paid, but its primary purpose is defining the meal break itself.

name: Meal Break Calculation Exclusion
rule_text: However, in calculating entitlement to a meal, the thirty (30) minute break shall not count as overtime work.
summary: The 30-minute paid meal break does not count as work time when determining eligibility for the next meal break.
reasoning: This rule clarifies how meal entitlements are calculated, specifying what time is excluded, making it a rule primarily about meal allowances.

name: Scheduled Overtime Meal Allowance In Lieu
rule_text: Scheduled Overtime ... a payment of thirty (30) minutes at the straight-time total package hourly rate in lieu of the meal break, and a fifteen (15) minute rest break at the applicable rate of pay.
summary: If a meal cannot be provided during scheduled overtime, the employee receives 30 minutes of pay at their straight-time total package rate and a 15-minute paid rest break instead.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type (llm) == 'SCHEDULED' AND meal_provided (llm) == false -> PAY(30_minutes_at_ST_total_package) AND PROVIDE(15_minute_paid_break)
reasoning: This rule specifies the monetary and time-based compensation provided when a meal entitlement is met with an allowance instead of a meal, which is central to the meal allowance topic.

name: Unscheduled Overtime Meal Allowance In Lieu
rule_text: Unscheduled Overtime ... a payment of forty dollars ($40.00) as a meal allowance. a payment of thirty (30) minutes at the straight-time total package hourly rate in the lieu of meal break, and a fifteen (15) minute rest break at the applicable rate of pay.
summary: If a meal cannot be provided during unscheduled overtime, the employee receives a $40 meal allowance, plus 30 minutes of pay at their straight-time total package rate, and a 15-minute paid rest break.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type (llm) == 'UNSCHEDULED' AND meal_provided (llm) == false -> ALLOWANCE($40) AND PAY(30_minutes_at_ST_total_package) AND PROVIDE(15_minute_paid_break)
reasoning: This rule defines the specific monetary and time-based payments for when a meal is not provided during unscheduled overtime, making it a core rule of the meal allowance topic.

name: Subsistence and Meal Allowance Interaction
rule_text: There shall be no meal allowance applicable to those receiving subsistence, however any reduction to the current subsistence rates will attract a meal allowance payment equivalent to the reduction.
summary: Employees receiving subsistence payments are not eligible for the overtime meal allowance, unless their subsistence rate is reduced, in which case they will receive a meal allowance equal to the amount of the reduction.
logical_representation: IF subsistence_provided (llm) == true -> FORFEIT(meal_allowance) UNLESS subsistence_rate_reduced (llm) == true
reasoning: This rule directly links eligibility for a meal allowance to the receipt of subsistence, making it primarily about meal allowances but with a strong connection to subsistence.

name: Camp and Meal Allowance Interaction
rule_text: Where a camp is provided, employees will not receive the forty dollars ($40.00) meal allowance where they are able to receive a camp meal at the end of their shift.
summary: If an employee is staying in a camp and can get a meal there after their shift, they are not eligible for the $40 meal allowance for unscheduled overtime.
logical_representation: IF camp_provided (llm) == true AND camp_meal_available (llm) == true -> FORFEIT(meal_allowance_$40)
reasoning: This rule specifies a condition (availability of a camp meal) that negates a monetary meal allowance, clearly placing it under the meal allowance topic.

name: Waiting Time Pay - First Two Days
rule_text: When an employee, on initial hire or transfer to a project, is instructed by the Employer to report to a job location on a certain day but is not placed to work until a later date, they shall be  entitled  to  two  (2)  hours  pay...for  each  of  the  first  two  (2) regular working days they are kept waiting.
summary: Upon initial hire or transfer, if an employee is told to report to a job but is not put to work, they receive 2 hours of pay for each of the first two regular working days they are kept waiting.
logical_representation: IF (employee_status == 'NEW_HIRE' OR employee_status == 'TRANSFER') AND waiting_day_count <= 2 -> PAY(2_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum payment for non-productive waiting time, which is a form of labor compensation and falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Waiting Time Pay - After Two Days
rule_text: Thereafter the waiting pay shall be increased to a full day of pay (i.e. eight (8) hours) for each regular working day. This waiting pay shall continue until the employee is given work or released from the job...
summary: If an employee on initial hire or transfer is kept waiting for work for more than two regular working days, their waiting pay increases to a full 8 hours for each subsequent waiting day until they start work or are released.
logical_representation: IF (employee_status == 'NEW_HIRE' OR employee_status == 'TRANSFER') AND waiting_day_count > 2 -> PAY(8_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule defines the amount of pay for a specific non-productive time scenario (extended waiting), which is a core component of labor time compensation.

name: Reporting Pay - Inclement Weather, No Work Started
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and cannot work because of inclement weather they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time and the employee must remain on the job for the two (2) hour period, unless otherwise instructed by the Employer's supervisor.
summary: If an employee reports to work but cannot start due to bad weather, they receive 2 hours of reporting pay. They must stay on the job for these two hours unless told otherwise by a supervisor.
logical_representation: IF work_commenced == false AND reason_for_no_work == 'INCLEMENT_WEATHER' -> PAY(2_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule specifies a minimum payment for reporting to work even if no work is performed, categorizing it as a rule for compensating an employee's time and availability.

name: Reporting Pay - Work Not Available
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and is not given the opportunity to work because none is available or was not advised before the completion of the previous day of work, they shall be paid two (2) hours of reporting time and allowed to leave the job immediately.
summary: If an employee reports to work as scheduled and there is no work for them, and they were not told the previous day not to come in, they receive 2 hours of reporting pay and can leave immediately.
logical_representation: IF work_available == false AND prior_notice_given == false -> PAY(2_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule guarantees payment for an employee's time and effort in reporting to a worksite, which is a form of compensation for labor time.

name: Subsistence for Waiting or Reporting Time
rule_text: An employee who is affected by the Conditions set out above shall be entitled to subsistence in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement.
summary: An employee who qualifies for waiting or reporting time pay is also entitled to receive subsistence pay as defined elsewhere in the agreement.
logical_representation: IF is_eligible_for_waiting_time == true OR is_eligible_for_reporting_time == true -> ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE)
reasoning: This rule explicitly grants a subsistence allowance based on waiting or reporting time conditions, making its primary topic LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE.

name: Reporting Pay Exception - 8-Hour Notice
rule_text: When an employee is notified eight (8) hours prior to the commencement of the scheduled starting time not to report for work, then such employee will not be entitled to any reporting time.
summary: An employee is not eligible for reporting pay if the employer gives them at least 8 hours' notice before their shift starts not to come to work.
reasoning: This rule provides a specific condition (sufficient notice) under which the entitlement to reporting pay is nullified, making it a rule governing labor time compensation.

name: Reporting Pay Exception - 1-Hour Notice on Camp Jobs
rule_text: On camp jobs, the notice time may be reduced to one (1) hour prior to starting time.
summary: For employees on camp jobs, the required notice from the employer to cancel a shift without paying reporting time is reduced from 8 hours to just 1 hour.
reasoning: This rule is a location-based modification of the conditions for reporting pay entitlement, directly affecting how labor time is compensated.

name: Reporting Pay Exception - Strike or Work Stoppage
rule_text: When an employee is unable to report for work due to a strike or work stoppage on the project where they are employed, such employee will not be entitled to any reporting time.
summary: If an employee cannot work because of a strike or work stoppage at their job site, they are not entitled to receive reporting pay.
reasoning: This rule outlines a specific circumstance (strike) that negates the reporting pay entitlement, thereby defining the boundaries of this labor time compensation.

name: Compensation for Work-Related Accident
rule_text: If an employee meets with an accident during working hours and available medical advice or proper medical considerations deem it unsafe for them to continue work, they shall be paid those amounts as compensation as prescribed in the Workers' Compensation Act and shall also receive any other applicable daily allowances until such time that the employee is no longer in Employer's care.
summary: If an employee has a work-related accident and cannot continue working for medical reasons, they will receive compensation as determined by the Workers' Compensation Act, plus any other daily allowances, until they are no longer in the employer's care.
logical_representation: IF is_workplace_accident == true AND is_medically_unfit_to_work == true -> PAY(WCB_COMPENSATION) AND ALLOWANCE(DAILY_ALLOWANCES)
reasoning: This rule specifies the compensation process for time lost due to a workplace injury, which is directly related to how an employee is paid for their scheduled or interrupted work time.

name: Pay for Camp Room Move
rule_text: Should an employee residing in camp accommodation be requested by the Employer or the Clients' designated camp management personnel to move to another room or camp, they are to do it during work hours and will be paid at appropriate rates or the employee shall be paid two (2) hours at the applicable straight time rate to carry out the move, if done outside work hours.
summary: If an employee in camp is asked to move rooms, the move should happen during paid work hours. If the move is done outside of regular work hours, the employee will be paid for 2 hours at their straight-time rate.
reasoning: This rule defines payment for a specific, employer-directed activity (moving rooms), treating it as compensable work time. Therefore, it falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Exception to Camp Room Move Pay
rule_text: This provision will not apply where employees are required to pack their room at the end of a work cycle or to facilitate a move that will occur during the employees furlough.
summary: Employees will not be paid for moving rooms if the move is part of the normal packing process at the end of a work cycle or if the move happens while they are on furlough.
logical_representation: IF project_location == 'CAMP_JOB' AND (reason_for_camp_move == 'END_OF_CYCLE' OR reason_for_camp_move == 'DURING_FURLOUGH') -> FORFEIT(CAMP_MOVE_PAY)
reasoning: This rule specifies conditions under which the camp move payment is forfeited. As it directly relates to a pay entitlement for a work-related activity, it is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Transportation for Camp Move
rule_text: Transportation will be supplied if required.
summary: If an employee is required to move camps, transportation will be provided by the employer if needed.
logical_representation: IF project_location == 'CAMP_JOB' AND is_transportation_required == true -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: This rule provides a non-monetary benefit related to a work requirement (moving camps). While not a direct pay rule, it's a condition of employment related to work activities, placing it within the scope of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Daily Travel - Employer Provided Transportation
rule_text: On those projects that are located between forty-five (45) radius kilometers to one hundred and twenty (120) radius kilometers from Edmonton and/or Calgary City Hall(s) or other Hiring Hall locations, the Employer shall supply suitable transportation to and from the project and mutually agreed to pick-up points.
summary: The employer must provide transportation for projects located between 45 and 120 radius kilometers from a city hall or hiring hall.
logical_representation: IF (project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 45 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) <= 120) OR (project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) > 45 AND project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) <= 120) -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: The rule describes an entitlement for employer-provided transportation based on project distance, which is a form of travel allowance and is therefore categorized under LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE.

name: Daily Travel - Kilometer Allowance
rule_text: Alternatively, the Employer shall pay to each employee a transportation cost at the rate of sixty-nine cents ($0.69) per road kilometer for each day worked or reported for work, from the edge of the forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone to the project and return.
summary: As an alternative to providing transportation, the employer can pay a daily travel allowance of $0.69 per kilometer for the distance from the 45km free zone to the project and back for projects between 45 and 120 km from a designated center.
logical_representation: IF ((project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 45 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) <= 120) OR (project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) > 45 AND project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) <= 120)) AND transportation_provided (llm) == false -> PAY(0.69 * road_kilometers_from_free_zone_return (llm))
reasoning: This rule specifies a monetary allowance for travel, which is a core component of subsistence and travel-related entitlements, thus fitting into the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Subsistence or Camp Eligibility
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid or camp provided on projects which are more than one hundred and twenty (120) radius kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary or other Hiring Hall locations.
summary: For projects over 120 radius kilometers from a city hall or hiring hall, the employer must either pay a subsistence allowance or provide a camp.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 120 OR project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) > 120 -> ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE) OR PROVIDE(CAMP)
reasoning: This rule establishes the primary distance-based condition for subsistence eligibility, which is the definition of the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Standard Subsistence Daily Rate
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid at a rate of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) per day worked or reported for.
summary: The standard daily subsistence rate is $150.00, paid for each day an employee works or reports for work.
logical_representation: IF is_eligible_for_subsistence (llm) == true AND is_location_specific_rate (llm) == false -> ALLOWANCE($150.00)
reasoning: The rule defines a specific monetary amount for a subsistence allowance, directly fitting the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Location-Specific Subsistence Daily Rates
summary: In certain specified locations, a different daily subsistence rate applies, overriding the standard $150.00 rate. Rates range from $125 to $205 depending on the area.
logical_representation: IF is_eligible_for_subsistence (llm) == true -> LOOKUP(project_location (Unsupported), {'Athabasca': 170.00, 'Bonnyville': 180.00, 'Calgary': 180.00, 'Camrose': 185.00, 'Caroline': 125.00, 'Canmore/Exshaw': 195.00, 'Cold Lake': 165.00, 'Drumheller': 180.00, 'Edmonton': 180.00, 'Edson': 175.00, 'Forestburg': 130.00, 'Fox Creek': 170.00, 'Fort McMurray': 200.00, 'Grande Cache': 160.00, 'Grande Prairie': 205.00, 'Hanna': 185.00, 'Hardisty/Wainwright': 170.00, 'High Level': 185.00, 'Hinton': 160.00, 'Lethbridge': 185.00, 'Lloydminster': 180.00, 'Medicine Hat': 170.00, 'Peace River': 185.00, 'Pincher Creek/Waterton': 160.00, 'Red Deer': 165.00, 'Rocky Mountain House': 190.00, 'Stettler': 190.00, 'Swan Hills': 150.00, 'Valley View': 165.00, 'Vermillion': 180.00, 'Wabasca': 200.00, 'Whitecourt': 155.00}) -> ALLOWANCE(lookup_result)
reasoning: This rule provides a list of exceptions and specific monetary amounts for subsistence allowances based on geography, which is a key aspect of defining subsistence entitlements.

name: Seven-Day Subsistence for Remote Projects
rule_text: On sites which are four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers plus as noted above, subsistence will be paid on a seven (7) day per week basis.
summary: For projects located 475 radius kilometers or more from a designated center, subsistence is paid for all seven days of the week, not just days worked.
reasoning: This rule modifies the payment frequency of the subsistence allowance based on project distance, which is a core component of the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Subsistence Forfeiture and Waiver for Absenteeism
rule_text: Forfeiture of subsistence allowance due to absenteeism may be waived if the reason for absence is acceptable to the Employer.
summary: An employee will lose their subsistence allowance if they are absent, but this forfeiture can be waived if the employer accepts the reason for the absence.
logical_representation: IF is_absent (llm) == true AND employer_accepts_reason (llm) == false -> FORFEIT(SUBSISTENCE); IF is_absent (llm) == true AND employer_accepts_reason (llm) == true -> WAIVE(FORFEITURE)
reasoning: This rule defines a condition (absenteeism) under which the subsistence allowance is forfeited or retained, a critical part of the rules governing the entitlement.

name: Additional Subsistence Day for Travel
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees not residing in the area where the project is located will be eligible to receive one additional day of subsistence for either the day before commencing work or the day after completing the work assignment, where the project is greater than two hundred (200) road kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary, or other Hiring Hall locations. This payment will be made for the preceding or succeeding day where substantiated by verifiable proof that accommodation was used (e.g., receipt or registration verification).
summary: Non-local employees on projects more than 200 road kilometers away can receive one extra day of subsistence for a travel day, either before starting or after finishing the job, provided they show proof of accommodation.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident (Unsupported) == false AND (project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 200 OR project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) > 200) AND claim_type (Unsupported) == 'RECEIPT_PROVIDED' -> ALLOWANCE(1_ADDITIONAL_DAY_SUBSISTENCE)
reasoning: This rule provides for an additional subsistence payment under specific travel and documentation conditions, making it a clear LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE rule.

name: Travel Allowance - Airfare Alternative
rule_text: or actual airfare if suitable proof of air transport is provided to the Employer.
summary: As an alternative to the set travel allowance amounts, an employee can be reimbursed for the actual cost of their airfare if they provide proof of air travel.
reasoning: This specifies an alternative form of reimbursement for travel costs, which is directly related to the subsistence and travel allowance topic.

name: Fort McMurray Initial and Terminal Travel Allowance
rule_text: Initial and Terminal travel for any project which falls within one- hundred (100) radius kilometers of Ft. McMurray city hall will be two hundred and ninety-seven dollars ($297.00).
summary: For projects within a 100km radius of Fort McMurray City Hall, the initial and terminal travel allowance is a flat $297.00.
reasoning: This is a location-specific monetary travel allowance, fitting under the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Travel Allowance Forfeiture - Client Provided Transport
rule_text: No travel shall be payable under this Article if the Client provides transportation to the work site and return.
summary: If the client provides transportation to and from the worksite, no travel allowance will be paid to the employee.
reasoning: This rule outlines a condition for the forfeiture of a travel allowance, which is an integral part of defining the entitlement.

name: Initial and Terminal Travel for Very Remote Projects (>475km)
rule_text: On jobs beyond the four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers initial and terminal travel amounts will be mutually agreed between the Local Lodge and the Employer to a maximum of four hundred and fifty-five dollars ($455.00) each way or airfare if suitable proof of air transport is provided to the Employer.
summary: For projects more than 475km away, initial and terminal travel will be a mutually agreed amount up to $455.00 each way, or the actual cost of airfare with proof.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 475 OR project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) > 475 -> PAY(MUTUALLY_AGREED_AMOUNT, MAX(455.00)) OR PAY(ACTUAL_AIRFARE)
reasoning: This rule defines the travel allowance for exceptionally distant projects, a key part of the subsistence and travel framework.

name: Payment Timing for Initial and Terminal Travel
rule_text: Initial travel amounts will be paid after fifteen (15) calendar days on the job or at lay- off. Terminal travel will be paid at lay-off.
summary: The initial travel allowance is paid after 15 calendar days of work or at layoff, whichever comes first. The terminal travel allowance is paid at layoff.
logical_representation: IF days_on_job (llm) >= 15 OR employee_status (Unsupported) == 'LAID_OFF' -> TRIGGER_PAYMENT(INITIAL_TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE); IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'LAID_OFF' -> TRIGGER_PAYMENT(TERMINAL_TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule governs the conditions and timing of payment for travel allowances, which is an administrative but crucial aspect of the entitlement.

name: Travel Allowance Forfeiture upon Quit or Termination
rule_text: Employees who quit or are terminated for cause prior to the entitlement payment of either initial or terminal amounts are not entitled to any travel payments outstanding.
summary: If an employee quits or is fired for cause before their travel allowances are due to be paid, they forfeit any outstanding travel payments.
reasoning: This rule specifies conditions related to employment status that lead to the forfeiture of the travel allowance, defining the limits of the entitlement.

name: Subsistence Eligibility Documentation Requirement
rule_text:
To qualify for the subsistence allowance under Article 16.01, the member, will supply two (2) of the following documents as verification of their name and current address. It is understood that the Employer will ensure any copies of such documents will be handled in accordance with PIPA regulations.
- Any government issued identification
- Utility Bill
- Bank Statement
- Vehicle Registration
- Housing Rental Agreement
- Mortgage Documentation
- Land Title
- Credit Card Statement
- Income Tax Assessment
- Property Tax Assessment
- Employment Insurance
summary: To be eligible for subsistence allowance, an employee must provide two specific forms of documentation from a provided list to verify their name and current address.
reasoning: This rule sets a non-monetary condition (documentation) for receiving the subsistence allowance, which is a fundamental part of the entitlement's rules.

name: Local Resident Entitlements on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees residing in the area where the project is located will not be eligible for Accommodation Allowance and initial/terminal travel but will receive daily travel payments pursuant to Article 16.01 (a) if they reside outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone around the project.
summary: On a subsistence project, local residents do not get subsistence or initial/terminal travel pay. However, they do receive daily travel pay if they live more than 45km from the project site.
logical_representation: IF project_is_subsistence (llm) == true AND is_local_resident (Unsupported) == true -> FORFEIT(SUBSISTENCE) AND FORFEIT(INITIAL_TERMINAL_TRAVEL); IF project_is_subsistence (llm) == true AND is_local_resident (Unsupported) == true AND employee_residence_distance_from_project (llm) > 45 -> ELIGIBLE(DAILY_TRAVEL_AS_PER_16.01a)
reasoning: This rule defines the specific allowances available or unavailable to a certain class of employee (local residents) on a subsistence project, making it a core subsistence rule.

name: Daily Travel for Non-Local Employees on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees domiciled outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer zone around the job will be provided transportation to and from the job or paid sixty-nine cents ($0.69) per road kilometer for each day worked or reported for work, from the edge of the free zone to the temporary domicile and return.
summary: On a subsistence project, non-local employees living in temporary housing more than 45km from the job site will either be given transportation or paid $0.69/km for daily travel between their temporary residence and the site.
logical_representation: IF project_is_subsistence (llm) == true AND is_local_resident (Unsupported) == false AND employee_temp_domicile_distance_from_project (llm) > 45 -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION) OR PAY(0.69 * road_kilometers_from_free_zone_return (llm))
reasoning: This rule covers daily travel entitlements for non-local employees already receiving subsistence, which is an extension of the subsistence and travel allowance framework.

name: Fort McMurray Daily Transportation on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: In Ft. McMurray, subsistence employees will be provided transportation to and from the job site as per current arrangements under the Agreement.
summary: In Fort McMurray, employees receiving subsistence will be provided with transportation to and from the job site according to existing arrangements.
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) == 'FT_MCMURRAY' AND project_is_subsistence (llm) == true -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: This is a location-specific rule about transportation provided in conjunction with subsistence, placing it within the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Pay Holdback Limit
rule_text: In no case shall more than five (5) regular working days be held back in any one payroll period.
summary: The employer cannot hold back more than five regular working days of pay in any payroll period.
reasoning: This rule sets a maximum limit on the time between work performed and payment, directly governing the payment process.

name: Final Pay Entitlement on Layoff or Discharge
rule_text: Employees who are laid off or discharged from the service of the Employer shall receive their wages and all monies owing and their Employment Insurance Contribution Certificate.
summary: Upon layoff or discharge, employees are entitled to receive all wages and money owed, along with their Employment Insurance documents.
reasoning: This rule defines the payment obligations of the employer upon termination of employment, which is a specific case of labor compensation rules.

name: Termination Slip Information Requirement
rule_text: the employee shall receive an Employer termination slip which shall show either their net pay and deductions, or the basic factors from which their pay will be calculated including: total pay hours, travel allowance and transportation allowances, subsistence, etc.
summary: Laid off or discharged employees must receive a termination slip detailing either their net pay and deductions or the factors used to calculate it, such as hours and allowances.
reasoning: This rule specifies the documentation and transparency required for final pay calculations, which is an administrative aspect of labor compensation.

name: Final Pay Method on Termination
rule_text: Pay shall be by direct deposit.
summary: When an employee is laid off or discharged, their final pay must be issued via direct deposit.
reasoning: This rule defines the method of payment for terminated employees, a procedural part of the labor compensation process.

name: Final Pay and ROE Deadline on Layoff or Discharge
rule_text: and the Employer shall direct deposit monies owing and file electronically the Record of Employment by the next regular scheduled pay period for the pay period in question, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday, and Recognized Holidays.
summary: For laid off or discharged employees, the employer must issue final pay and the Record of Employment by the next regular payday for that pay period, excluding weekends and holidays.
reasoning: This rule sets the deadline for final payment upon termination, a critical timing aspect of labor compensation.

name: Late Final Pay Penalty on Layoff or Discharge
rule_text: Should the Employer fail to comply with this provision (excluding the reference to the Record of Employment), the employee shall receive an additional sum equivalent to eight (8) hours of pay at straight time rates for each day they are kept waiting exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Statutory Holidays up to a maximum of forty (40) hours of pay.
summary: If an employer is late with the final payment for a laid off or discharged employee, they must pay a penalty of 8 hours of straight-time pay for each waiting day (excluding weekends/holidays), up to a maximum of 40 hours.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'DISCHARGED'] AND final_pay_is_late (llm) == true -> PAY(8_HOURS_ST * days_late (llm), MAX=40_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty for failing to meet payment deadlines, which is directly related to labor compensation.

name: Final Pay and ROE Deadline on Quitting
rule_text: When an employee quits of their own volition, the Employer shall direct deposit all monies owing and file electronically the Record of Employment by the next regular scheduled pay period for the pay period in question, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Recognized Holidays.
summary: When an employee quits, the employer must issue their final pay and Record of Employment by the next regular payday for that pay period, excluding weekends and holidays.
reasoning: This rule sets the deadline for final payment for employees who resign, a critical timing aspect of labor compensation.

name: Late Final Pay Penalty on Quitting
rule_text: If the Employer fails to comply with this requirement within five (5) working days after the specified pay day, the employee shall receive an additional sum equivalent to eight (8) hours of pay at straight time rates.
summary: If an employer is more than five working days late with the final pay for an employee who has quit, the employee is entitled to a one-time penalty payment of 8 hours of straight-time pay.
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty for failing to meet payment deadlines for employees who quit, which is directly related to labor compensation.

name: Employee Obligation to Report Pay Shortage
rule_text: If on an employee's weekly paycheck, they are shorted pay, the employee is required to notify the Employer immediately in writing.
summary: Employees who are shorted on their paycheck must notify the employer immediately and in writing.
reasoning: This rule establishes the required process for an employee to initiate a pay correction, which is an administrative rule governing labor compensation.

name: Pay Shortage Correction Deadline
rule_text: The Employer shall provide an adjustment on a subsequent pay date but not later than ten (10) days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays, and Recognized Holidays after receiving the notification of the shortage in writing.
summary: After receiving a written notice of a pay shortage, the employer must correct the error within 10 days, excluding weekends and holidays.
reasoning: This rule sets a deadline for the employer to rectify pay errors, a key timing aspect of ensuring correct labor compensation.

name: Penalty for Late Pay Shortage Correction
rule_text: Should this payment not be made within the allotted ten (10) days, the Employer will pay one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day the employee is kept waiting from the date the notification of shortage was received in writing by the Employer to a maximum of seven hundred dollars ($700.00).
summary: If the employer fails to correct a pay shortage within the 10-day limit, they must pay a penalty of $100 for each day of delay, starting from the original notification date, up to a maximum of $700.
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty for failing to correct pay errors on time, directly related to enforcing labor compensation rules.

name: Bereavement Pay Entitlement
rule_text: For those employees with more than three (3) years of continuous service with one (1) Employer, the employee will be entitled to bereavement pay benefits of eight (8) hours multiplied by the employees' base wage rate for up to three (3) days of lost work incurred as a results of the employee's attendance at a funeral or memorial service upon the death of an employee's Spouse, Child, Parent, Parent -in-Law, Grandparent or Sibling. Bereavement Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate.
summary: Employees with over 3 years of continuous service are entitled to up to 3 days of bereavement pay (8 hours per day at straight-time rate) for lost work to attend a funeral for a close family member. This service requirement is subject to change in 2026 and 2027.
logical_representation: IF continuous_service_years (llm) > 3 AND bereavement_relationship (llm) IN ['SPOUSE', 'CHILD', 'PARENT', 'PARENT_IN_LAW', 'GRANDPARENT', 'SIBLING'] -> PAY(8_HOURS_ST * lost_work_days (llm), MAX_DAYS=3)
reasoning: This rule establishes an entitlement to paid leave under specific circumstances, defining eligibility and calculation method, which falls under labor compensation rules.

name: Subsistence Reimbursement Receipt Requirements
rule_text:
The following information must appear on all receipts:

1. Date
2. Name of Establishment and Name of Contact Person if appropriate (see examples below) ABC Motel -Company letterhead receipt -Name of Contact Person not required B & B or Relative (non-registered) -Name of Contact Person required
3. Complete Address and Phone Number of the Establishment
4. Employee's Full Name
5. Reason/Description of Cost (including dates)
6. Total Cost
summary: To receive subsistence reimbursement, a receipt must contain specific information: the date, establishment name, its full address and phone number, the employee's full name, a description of the cost including dates, and the total cost.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' AND (receipt_has_date (llm) == false OR receipt_has_establishment_name (llm) == false OR receipt_has_establishment_address (llm) == false OR receipt_has_establishment_phone (llm) == false OR receipt_has_employee_name (llm) == false OR receipt_has_cost_description (llm) == false OR receipt_has_total_cost (llm) == false) -> FORFEIT(ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE))
reasoning: This rule outlines the mandatory fields required on a receipt for an employee to be reimbursed for subsistence. It is a core administrative requirement for the subsistence allowance benefit.

name: Subsistence Receipt Contact Person Requirement
rule_text: Name of Contact Person if appropriate (see examples below) ABC Motel -Company letterhead receipt -Name of Contact Person not required B & B or Relative (non-registered) -Name of Contact Person required
summary: For subsistence reimbursement, a receipt from a non-registered establishment (like a B&B or a relative's home) must include a contact person's name. This is not required for receipts from registered establishments like motels.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' AND establishment_type (llm) == 'NON-REGISTERED' AND receipt_has_contact_person (llm) == false -> FORFEIT(ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE))
reasoning: This rule specifies a conditional requirement for subsistence reimbursement based on the type of accommodation (registered vs. non-registered), which directly affects the validity of the claim.

name: Rejection of Incomplete Subsistence Receipts
rule_text: A receipt without complete or required information will not be considered.
summary: A claim for subsistence reimbursement will be rejected if the submitted receipt is missing any of the required information.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' AND is_receipt_complete (llm) == false -> FORFEIT(ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE))
reasoning: This rule states the direct consequence of failing to meet the informational requirements for a subsistence receipt, making it a critical enforcement clause for the allowance.

name: EDO Allocation
rule_text: Of the twentysix (26) EDO's, eighteen (18) will be scheduled by Suncor and the remaining eight (8) will be designated as flex EDO's to be taken as mutually agreed between the employee and the supervisor.
summary: Out of 26 annual Earned Days Off (EDOs), 18 are scheduled by the company (Suncor), and the remaining 8 are flexible EDOs to be scheduled by mutual agreement between the employee and supervisor.
logical_representation: IF earned_days_off (llm) == 26 -> ALLOCATE(18, edo_type (llm)='SCHEDULED_BY_COMPANY') AND ALLOCATE(8, edo_type (llm)='FLEX')
reasoning: This rule outlines the entitlement and administration of paid days off, which is an integral part of managing and compensating labor time.

name: Long Term Employee Definition
rule_text: It is understood that when an employee is hired with the intentions of an employment term of more than a six (6) week period, that employee will be automatically on the aforementioned Compressed Work Week arrangements and be considered as a Long Term Base Crew employee.
summary: An employee hired with the expectation of working for more than six weeks is automatically classified as a Long Term Base Crew employee and placed on the Compressed Work Week schedule.
reasoning: This rule defines the criteria for employee classification, which directly determines the applicable work schedule and pay rules for their worked hours.

name: Early Termination Pay Adjustment
rule_text: Should an employee be terminated prior to working six (6) weeks, an adjustment shall be made in accordance with the terms of Clause b).
summary: If a long-term employee is terminated before working for six weeks, their pay will be recalculated based on the rules for short-term employees (Clause b).
reasoning: This rule dictates a retroactive pay calculation based on employment duration and status, which is a direct rule for processing labor time and wages.

name: Transition to Long Term Crew Status
rule_text: Should the employee be employed onsite after six (6) weeks on the job, that employee will then be considered part of the Long Term Crew and paid in in accordance with the Compressed Work Week payment terms
summary: If a short-term employee works for more than six weeks, they are reclassified as a Long Term Crew member and will be paid according to the Compressed Work Week terms from that point forward.
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'SHORT_TERM' AND employment_duration_weeks (llm) > 6 -> SET(employee_type (llm)='LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW') AND APPLY_PAY_RULES('COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK')
reasoning: This rule defines the trigger for changing an employee's classification and their corresponding pay rules, directly impacting how their worked time is billed.

name: Flex EDO Work Request Condition
rule_text: Once scheduled, requests for employees to work on flex days will only be made a last resort, after all reasonable options are made to find alternate arrangements.
summary: The company may only request an employee to work on a scheduled flex day as a last resort, after all other reasonable staffing options have been exhausted.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: Request to work on day_type (llm) == 'FLEX_EDO' must be a last resort.
reasoning: This rule sets an operational constraint on scheduling work on days off, which is related to managing labor time and availability.

name: Termination Pay Adjustment, No Recent Flex EDO
rule_text: If a long term employee is terminated without having a flex EDO within the previous six (6) weeks, then an adjustment will be made to pay any regular hours worked in excess of two hundred and forty (240) hours over the previous six (6) weeks at the applicable overtime rate.
summary: If a long-term employee is terminated and has not taken a flex EDO in the prior six weeks, any regular hours they worked above 240 during that six-week period will be retroactively paid at the overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' AND employee_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW' AND flex_edo_taken_in_lookback (llm) == false AND lookback_period_weeks (llm) == 6 AND hours_in_lookback_period (llm) > 240 -> PAY(OT_RATE, hours = hours_in_lookback_period (llm) - 240)
reasoning: This rule dictates a specific pay adjustment upon termination based on hours worked and time off taken, making it a worked time calculation rule.

name: Flex EDO Request Notice Period
rule_text: The employee will provide a minimum of seven (7) days notice when requesting flex. EDO's.
summary: Employees must give at least seven days' notice when requesting to use a flexible Earned Day Off (EDO).
reasoning: This rule governs the procedure for taking time off, which is a component of managing labor time and scheduling.

name: Flex EDO Request Notice Exception
rule_text: Special circumstances will be considered by the supervisor wherein a shorter notice period may be allowed.
summary: A supervisor can approve a flexible EDO request with less than seven days' notice under special circumstances.
logical_representation: IF special_circumstances (llm) == true -> ALLOW(request(day_type (llm)='FLEX_EDO') with notice_period_days (llm) < 7)
reasoning: This rule provides an exception to the standard procedure for requesting time off, which is related to managing labor worked time.

name: Flex EDO Request Responsibility
rule_text: It is understood that: the onus is on the employee to request the flex EDO's;
summary: It is the employee's responsibility to request and schedule their flexible Earned Days Off.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: Employee is responsible for requesting day_type (llm) == 'FLEX_EDO'
reasoning: This rule clarifies responsibility for scheduling time off, which is a part of labor time management.

name: No Payout for Unused Flex EDO
rule_text: overtime payment will not be made for flex days not taken by the employee with the exception of those circumstances outlined in items b) and c) above
summary: Employees will not receive an overtime payout for any unused flexible EDOs, unless specific conditions related to termination or other pay adjustments (as outlined in clauses b and c) are met.
logical_representation: IF day_type (llm) == 'FLEX_EDO' AND is_unused == true -> FORFEIT(overtime_payment) UNLESS condition in (clause_b OR clause_c)
reasoning: This rule defines the financial treatment of unused time off, which is a core labor billing rule concerning compensation for time not worked.

name: Plant Shutdown, Extended Short Term Status
rule_text: Those hired for the Plant Shutdown will continue to receive compensation under the terms of short term employment until the conclusion of the work even if they are on site longer than six (6) weeks.
summary: Employees hired specifically for a Plant Shutdown will be paid as short-term employees for the entire duration of the shutdown work, even if it lasts longer than six weeks.
logical_representation: IF hired_for_event (llm) == 'PLANT_SHUTDOWN' -> SET(employee_type (llm)='SHORT_TERM') for DURATION(event (Unsupported)='PLANT_SHUTDOWN') REGARDLESS of employment_duration_weeks (llm) > 6
reasoning: This rule creates an exception to the standard reclassification of employees based on a specific project event, which directly impacts their pay structure and how their time is billed.

name: Plant Shutdown, Long Term Crew Compensation
rule_text: All Long Term Base Crew employees shall remain on the compensation terms of the Compressed Work Week arrangements where applicable overtime payments will be made for work on a scheduled day off as per Clause c).
summary: During a Plant Shutdown, Long Term Base Crew employees continue to be paid under their normal Compressed Work Week terms, and any work on a scheduled day off is paid as overtime according to standard rules.
reasoning: This rule confirms that the standard pay rules for a specific employee class remain in effect during a special event, which is an important clarification for labor time billing.

name: EDO Work Pay Rate, IOL Strathcona
rule_text: Overtime payments for work on the sixteen (16) scheduled EDO's will be paid at double (2x).
summary: For employees on the IOL Strathcona schedule, any work performed on a scheduled Earned Day Off (EDO) must be paid at double the regular rate.
reasoning: This rule defines a specific pay rate (double time) for work performed on a special type of day (EDO), which is a key component of classifying and calculating pay for worked time, fitting the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Penalty for Insufficient Shift Change Notice
rule_text: An employee will be given twenty-four (24) hours advance notice prior to the start of their new shift and if not then they shall be paid their first shift at time and one-half (1 ½x).
summary: If an employee is not given at least 24 hours' notice before a shift change, their entire first shift on the new schedule must be paid at time and a half.
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule imposes a premium pay rate (time and a half) as a penalty for insufficient notice, directly altering the pay calculation for worked time.

name: Shift Change Pay for Lost Hours
rule_text: If an employee loses time on their initial Compressed Work Week schedule due to having their Compressed Work Week schedule changed to a new Compressed Work Week schedule, they shall be paid for those hours they would have worked on their initial schedule up to the start of their new schedule.
summary: If a shift change between two Compressed Work Week schedules causes an employee to lose scheduled work hours, they must be paid for the hours they missed on their original schedule.
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule provides for payment of hours not actually worked due to a schedule change, which is a form of guaranteed pay and falls under the topic of worked time compensation.

name: Prorated Earned Days Off
rule_text: If a fraction of the regular work days are worked the same fraction of the immediately following regular days off are earned. Any fraction of a day shall be considered one day when calculating earned days off.
summary: If an employee only works part of their scheduled work days before their days off, they earn a proportional amount of those days off. When calculating this, any fraction of a day off earned is rounded up to a full day.
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule defines the calculation for an entitlement (earned days off) based on time worked, which is fundamental to scheduling and pay.

name: Bereavement Pay Entitlement
rule_text: For those employees with more than three (3) years of service with an Employer, the employee will be entitled to bereavement pay benefits of eight (8) hours multiplied by the employees' base wage rate for up to three (3) days of lost work incurred as a result of the employee's attendance at a funeral or memorial service upon the death of an employee's Spouse, Child, Parent, Parent -inLaw, Grandparent or Sibling. Bereavement Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate.
summary: An employee with more than 3 years of service is entitled to up to 3 days of paid bereavement leave (8 hours per day at straight time) to attend a funeral for an immediate family member (Spouse, Child, Parent, Parent-in-Law, Grandparent, or Sibling).
logical_representation: IF years_of_service (llm) > 3 AND bereavement_reason (llm) IN ['SPOUSE', 'CHILD', 'PARENT', 'PARENT_IN_LAW', 'GRANDPARENT', 'SIBLING'] -> PAY(MAX_3_DAYS * 8_HOURS_ST)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule provides for paid time off under specific circumstances, which is a form of compensation for time and falls under the LABOR_WORKED_TIME category.

name: Vacation Pay Tiers (Long-Term Maintenance)
summary: For long-term maintenance employees, vacation pay is a percentage of earnings based on years of service: 6% (0-3 yrs), 7% (3-7 yrs), 8% (7-10 yrs), 9% (10-12 yrs), and 10% (over 12 yrs).
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule defines the calculation rate for vacation pay, which is a direct component of an employee's total compensation for their labor, fitting squarely in LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Continuity of Service for Vacation Pay
rule_text: Long term maintenance employees who have a break in service with the Employer will maintain their years of service should the break in service be less than ninety (90) calendar days. A change to the commercial contract whereby an individual is moved from one Signatory Employer to another shall not be considered a break in service. The break in service is not applicable for those who quit or are terminated.
summary: For long-term maintenance employees, years of service (used for calculating vacation pay) are maintained if a break in employment is less than 90 days. Moving between signatory employers is not considered a break in service. This does not apply to employees who quit or are terminated.
logical_representation: IF maintenance_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM' AND break_in_service_days (llm) < 90 AND employee_status (Unsupported) NOT IN ['QUIT', 'TERMINATED'] -> MAINTAIN(years_of_service (llm))
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule defines how a key metric ('years of service') is maintained or reset, which directly impacts pay entitlements like vacation pay, making it a rule related to labor compensation.

name: Maintenance Work Wage Rate
rule_text: Wage rates for maintenance work shall be $0.75 per hour less than base rates set forth in the Area Labour Agreement of the Member Union where such work is to be performed and shall be paid to all employees under the terms of this agreement.
summary: For maintenance work, employees are paid $0.75 per hour less than the base rate specified in the relevant Area Labour Agreement.
reasoning: This rule defines the calculation of a wage rate for a specific type of work, which is a core component of how worked time is compensated.

name: Optional Electronic Pay Records
rule_text: At the Employer's option, electronic pay records and records of Employment may be provided in lieu of  printed  records.
summary: The employer can choose to provide pay records and Records of Employment electronically instead of as printed documents.
reasoning: This rule pertains to the administration and delivery of pay information, which is directly related to the compensation for worked time.

name: Printed Pay Records on Request
rule_text: Upon  request  from  an  employee  that  does  not  have  the  capability  to  access electronic records, printed pay records shall be issued.
summary: If an employee cannot access electronic records and requests them, the employer must provide printed pay records.
logical_representation: IF employee_request (llm) == 'PRINTED_PAY_RECORDS' AND access_capability (llm) == false -> PROVIDE('PRINTED_PAY_RECORDS')
reasoning: This rule establishes an employee's entitlement to a specific format of pay information, making it part of the administration of worked time compensation.

name: Printed Record of Employment on Request
rule_text: Upon request, a printed record of employment will be issued.
summary: An employee can request a printed Record of Employment, and the employer must provide it.
reasoning: This rule defines an employee's right concerning their employment records, which are linked to their history of worked time and pay.

name: Ft. McMurray Maintenance Wage Rate
rule_text: For projects that are located within a one hundred (100) radius kilometers of Ft. McMurray city hall, wage rates for maintenance shall be 100% of base rates set forth in the Area Labour Agreement.
summary: For maintenance work on projects within a 100 km radius of Ft. McMurray city hall, the wage rate is 100% of the base rate from the Area Labour Agreement, with no reduction.
reasoning: This rule is a location-based exception that sets a specific wage rate, directly impacting the compensation for worked time.

name: Enablement Provisions Parity
rule_text: Any enablement provisions made by the Local Unions to the wage rates or benefits  packages and provided to any Employer will be extended to NMA Employers when bidding the same or similar work packages. In these circumstances' maintenance will be at the enabled conditions.
summary: If a Local Union offers special, more favorable wage or benefit conditions ('enablement provisions') to any employer, those same conditions must be extended to NMA Employers bidding on similar work.
logical_representation: IF enablement_provision (llm) == true FOR work_type (llm) -> APPLY_CONDITIONS('enablement_provision')
reasoning: This rule ensures parity in wage and benefit rates under specific circumstances, directly impacting how worked time is compensated.

name: Monetary Change Implementation Timeline
rule_text: Upon renewal of a Local Reference Agreement the Employer will have thirty (30) days from receipt of notification to implement any initial monetary changes.
summary: After a Local Reference Agreement is renewed, the employer has 30 days from being notified to implement any new monetary changes.
reasoning: This rule governs the timing for applying new wage or benefit calculations, which is an administrative aspect of compensating for worked time.

name: Retroactive Pay on Renewal
rule_text: Payment of any initial increase will be paid retroactively to the implementation date.
summary: When a new agreement increases pay, the increase is paid retroactively back to the official implementation date.
reasoning: This rule dictates how wage increases are calculated and paid out for past worked time, making it a core worked time compensation rule.

name: Alloy Welder Premium Non-Pyramiding
rule_text: This premium shall not pyramid on an overtime hour; however, it will attract applicable Vacation and Statutory Holiday Pay.
summary: The alloy welder premium is a flat hourly addition and is not multiplied by overtime rates.
reasoning: This rule specifies how a premium is calculated in relation to overtime, directly impacting the total compensation for worked time.

name: Alloy Welder Premium on Vacation and Holiday Pay
rule_text: This premium shall not pyramid on an overtime hour; however, it will attract applicable Vacation and Statutory Holiday Pay.
summary: The alloy welder premium is included in the calculation for an employee's Vacation and Statutory Holiday Pay.
reasoning: This rule defines how a premium affects other pay calculations (Vacation/Stat Holiday pay), which is a key part of total compensation for worked time.

name: Final Pay on Termination
rule_text: Employees who are laid off or terminated from the services of the Company shall normally receive their final wages, vacation pay due, and unemployment insurance record of earnings before they leave the jobsite.
summary: Normally, when an employee is laid off or terminated, they must receive their final pay, vacation pay, and Record of Employment (ROE) before leaving the jobsite.
reasoning: This rule governs the process and timing for issuing final payment for all worked time upon termination, making it an administrative rule for labor compensation.

name: Final Pay by Mail Exception
rule_text: It is recognized that there will be certain occasions when the above procedure is not possible. In these cases final wages, vacation pay due, and Records of Earnings (ROE's) will be mailed to the employee's last recorded  home  address  within  three  (3)  working  days  exclusive  of  Saturdays,  Sundays  and Statutory  Holidays.
summary: If it's not possible to provide final pay on-site at termination, the company must mail the final pay and Record of Employment (ROE) to the employee's last known address within three business days.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'TERMINATED'] AND on_site_payment_not_possible (llm) == true -> MAIL(final_pay_and_roe, within=3_business_days)
reasoning: This rule provides an alternative procedure and timeline for issuing final payment for worked time, classifying it under labor compensation administration.

name: ROE Filing and Mailing
rule_text: EI  Records  of  Earnings  (ROE's)  will  be  filed  electronically  or  at  the  employees' written request be mailed Express Post to the employees' last recorded home address within three (3) working days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and Statutory Holidays.
summary: Records of Employment (ROEs) will be filed electronically. However, if an employee makes a written request, the ROE will be sent by Express Post to their last known address within three business days.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'TERMINATED'] AND employee_request (llm) == 'MAILED_ROE' -> MAIL(roe_express_post, within=3_business_days) ELSE FILE(roe_electronically, within=3_business_days)
reasoning: This rule specifies the method and deadline for providing employment records tied to an employee's worked time and earnings, falling under the administration of labor compensation.

name: Final Pay with Electronic Deposit
rule_text: When electronic deposits are made, the final deposit and other termination document mailings/filings must be made by the next pay period.
summary: If final pay is made by electronic deposit, the payment and all associated termination documents must be processed by the next regular pay period.
